Beyond the Observable Universe is Heaven

The Physicists Have It Wrong

Suns and galaxies are moving away from us; and the farther away, the faster they recede from us.
Physicists say that suns moving away from us faster than the speed of light will emit starlight that will never reach us.

I believe that to be an incorrect geocentric vision of the universe. Under their
formula, we should be able to choose a star somewhat closer, who’s starlight
would arrive here going 3 miles per hour. Doesn’t seem reasonable!

What they are missing is that the speed of light “c” is constant, but is relative, not
to the earth, but to wherever the light, or photon, is.

Turn their situation backwards and send light from here to there. As light goes from here to some nearby galaxy, the light is moving at speed “c” relative to that
galaxy, so it seems from earth to be going at “c” plus the recession speed of the galaxy. As light gets farther away, its speed seems to increase when seen from earth.
Also light from very distant stars, may seem to have a negative speed towards us,
but from that distant viewpoint it is constantly speeding up.

Starlight from everywhere is constantly speeding up and arrives here at speed “c”
having traveled through every point at speed “c” relative to that point.
Starlight going outward also increases speed relative to earth to maintain
speed “c” relative to where it is at any given moment.
We will notice the red-shift as an indication of how far the light has traveled.

Conclusion: The idea of an “Observable Universe” is wrong.

how do they know the universe is 13.8 billion years?

The Universe is 13.8 billion years old and the edge of the Observable Universe is 46.5 billion light years away, how do you explain that. We know we are not seeing what it was like 46.5 billion years ago, since time and it didn’t exist then!
Imagine you had 25 people standing in 5 lines of 5 to represent the singularity, then free space grew by 1 metre between each of them so they would now all be a metre apart. The middle did not move faster than the edges because none of the people actually moved in free space. There was relative velocity between the people but no real velocity since none of them had actually moved through free space. If originally the 25 people were standing on black crosses, they would still be standing on the same black crosses after the expansion. Each person had a zero displacement, therefore zero velocity. Whichever person was the observer, they would see all the other people going away from them, the people furthest from them would have had the biggest relative velocity to them. Imagine you were a person at the end of one of these lines of 5 people. The nearest person to you would have moved an extra 1 metre from you while the person at the other end of the line would have moved 4 metres from you. If you now imagined there were millions of people and they all moved an extra metre apart due to the expansion of free space between each of them how the furthest person could have had a RELATIVE velocity exceeding the speed of light. This also explains why the edge of our Observable Universe is about 46.5 billion light years away even though the Universe is only 13.8 billion years old. The most distant galaxies didn’t have to move faster than the speed of light in a vacuum, it was free space expanding the space-time away from us faster than the speed of light that enabled them to be that far away.

OK, So I am having an issue with the Spotlight analogy. GNZ11 emittedthe light that we see when it was 13.4 billion light years away. We know that the Universe is only 13.8 billion years old. So, to my thinking, it can only be 400million light years + expansion further to the edge. So a spotlight centred in GNZ11 would be full of galaxies 46.5 billion LY in the direction of the earth but a much smaller distance in the direction away from earth. Also, given that humanity is only 120,000 years old, it is highly likely that a civilization has formed in GNZ11 or a neighbouring galaxy which has developed a telescope with similar capabilities to hubble. If they look away from earth how far can they see? My guess is that they can only see 400 million LY + expansion. If this is so, then maybe the speed of light has changed since the dawning of the universe and is now much faster than it once was.

Fully expecting someone to correct my niaivity here and looking forward to being put firmly in my place.

hey there, I'm no scientist or an astronomer, but isn't possible that the light coming from that farthest galaxy is coming to us in kind of an zigzag way? Like on it's way to earth, it turned (let's say 90°) when passing by an massive object (black hole), then the light was basically travelling on an 90° angle from earth for a long time. Then again the same thing happened (at different angles, multiple times) and light was again coming towards earth. It also means that it's possible the galaxy is not even in that direction that we are looking towards. So basically the light didn't come to us in a straight way, and took multiple turns, that's probably why the source of light is 32 billion years away.
I realised it when i was typing that the light still has to travel for 32 billion years but the universe is only 13.4 billion years, well, all we can say that time doesn't work the same way out there in space, (neither light and gravity and everything else) as it works on earth.
So let's just consider we still don't know about 99% of astronomical stuff even after studying all these years.

But i do believe that we will have the answer in maybe 5-6 decades.
